text: The firelight flickered against the walls, wrapping the tavern in a quiet golden haze. Her gaze lingered on me—curious, searching, almost tender.
“I’ll try to change my fate,” I said. My voice was calm—steadier than I’d expected.
She blinked, as if my answer had caught her off guard. The firelight reflected softly in her eyes, and for a brief moment, she smiled.
“Maybe you really can,” she said quietly. “Some people can negotiate with fate—instead of being dragged by it.”
She lifted her glass but didn’t drink. Her eyes rested on the glow within, and for that moment, she seemed softened by the light.
“I’ve seen many crushed under fate’s weight,” she murmured. “But I’ve also seen—someone who smiled and stood tall before it.”
She froze for a heartbeat, then gave a soft, helpless laugh. “Me? I’ve never beaten it.”
The flames swayed, and the faint sound of snow drifted from outside. Her smile was tinged with sorrow—but it no longer felt distant.
“If that day ever comes…” she said, “I hope you won’t regret it. Fate always demands a price for every chance it gives.”
“And you?” I asked quietly. “Do you regret it?”
She didn’t answer. She simply raised her glass and drank it all. The liquid caught the firelight—like molten amber in motion.
“Fate is stubborn,” she said softly, setting the glass down. Then she smiled at me—warmly, almost gently. “But maybe… you’ll be the exception.”
The fire danced in her eyes, and her smile lingered there—half light, half shadow—long after the flames had begun to fade.
